question_feedback.student_choice: A hub, because it creates a single collision domain where all devices compete for bandwidth
question_feedback.correct_answer: A hub, because it creates a single collision domain where all devices compete for bandwidth
question_feedback.explanation: A hub operates at the physical layer and creates one large collision domain where all connected devices share the total bandwidth. When one device transmits heavily, it monopolizes the shared medium, causing slowdowns for all other devices.

question_feedback.student_choice: When you need to route packets between different IP subnets
question_feedback.correct_answer: When you need to connect two different network segments and have budget constraints for a simple, low-port-count solution
question_feedback.analysis: The correct answer was: When you need to connect two different network segments and have budget constraints for a simple, low-port-count solution
question_feedback.explanation: Bridges are primarily used to connect two network segments and are typically simpler and less expensive than switches. While switches have largely replaced bridges, bridges might still be used in simple scenarios where only two segments need connection.

question_feedback.student_choice: Router - it will examine the destination IP address and determine the next hop
question_feedback.correct_answer: Router - it will examine the destination IP address and determine the next hop
question_feedback.explanation: A router operates at Layer 3 (Network layer) and uses IP addresses to determine the best path for packets between different networks. Since these IP addresses are on different networks, a router is needed to route the packets.

question_feedback.student_choice: A switch floods unknown frames to all ports except the source, while a hub repeats all signals to all ports
question_feedback.correct_answer: A switch floods unknown frames to all ports except the source, while a hub repeats all signals to all ports
question_feedback.explanation: When a switch receives a frame for an unknown MAC address (not in its MAC address table), it floods the frame to all ports except the source port. A hub simply repeats all electrical signals to all ports regardless of the destination.

question_feedback.student_choice: A gateway, because it can translate between different protocol stacks
question_feedback.correct_answer: A gateway, because it can translate between different protocol stacks
question_feedback.explanation: A gateway operates at multiple layers and can translate between different protocol stacks, such as converting IPX protocol communications to TCP/IP. This protocol translation capability is what distinguishes gateways from other network devices.
